It starts with her early life in Boise, her life with her husband (Carl) in Meridian, her journey to and from Canada and much more. It is a fascinating read and discusses the hardships and happy days of life in Meridian and beyond.

title: Herbert Grant
description: A Meridian Times "Men About..." article documenting the life of Herbert Grant. Mr. Grant led an exciting and varied life prior to ending up in Meridian. Born in Wendell, Idaho, his family moved to Emmett when he was a child. After a short stay in South Dakota, he moved back to Idaho and manned a lookout for the Forest Service. He entered the Navy in 1943 and was sent to England where he performed ship repairs and several other duties. After three years in the Navy, he returned to Idaho where he met his wife, Dolores. After spending time as a logger and sustaining an injury, he made his way to Meridian and worked at the phone exchange. In total, Herb and Dolores had three children: James, Janice Marie and Susan. His record of community service to Meridian is long and impressive.
subject: newspaper articles;biographies

title: Glenn Edgar Green
description: A Meridian Times "Man About..." article documenting the life of Glenn Edgar Green. Mr. Green's family came to Idaho from Kansas, residing in Eagle. His family weathered the Great Depression. Shortly after high school, Glenn married Mayme in 1942 and he went to work for his father's tool company. The couple had two children: Jack and Barbara Ann and eventually opened their own business. Glenn and Mayme were active members of the Methodist church and Glenn was a member of the Boy Scout council, Lion's Club and Jaycees Booster club.
subject: newspaper articles;biographies

title: "Mrs. Gregory, Pioneer Resident of Meridian Dies"

After her first husband was killed in an Indian attack, she married George E. Gregory. They had two children and moved to Meridian in 1891. She lived a life of community service and gratitude and her funeral was well-attended.
subject: newspaper articles;obituaries

She leaves behind four children, 15 grandchildren and 26 great-grandchildren.

title: Daniel Vincent Lopez De Vinaspre
description: Handwritten document on the life of Daniel Lopez. His father came to Meridian from Spain in 1903 and his mother followed in 1907. Daniel was born in 1908 and grew up on the Ten Mile Stock Farm and attended Meridian High School. He graduated in 1928, and in 1932 he graduated from the University of Idaho. Unable to find employment during the great depression, he decided to try professional wrestling. After many successful years as a wrestler, he decided to leave the wrestling world and purchase some land in Costa Rica. He used the land to harvest timber and grow coffee. He married Juanita Lackman and they had a happy life in Costa Rica. In 1980, he decided to sell his plantation and return to Meridian. Sadly, he passed away during this time period.
